revision.comment: remove extraneous spaces at end of line
revision.text:
==English== {{wikipedia}} ===Pronunciation=== {{rfp|en}} ===Etymology 1=== From the {{bor|en|cmn-pinyin|-}} romanization of the {{bor|en|cmn|-}} Chinese pronunciation for {{zh-l|興江}}. ====Proper noun==== {{en-proper noun}} # {{place|en|township|county/Xingguo|prefecture-level city/Ganzhou|p/Jiangxi|c/China}} =====Translations===== {{trans-top|township}} * Chinese: *: Mandarin: {{t|cmn|興江|sc=Hani}}, {{t|cmn|兴江|tr=Xīngjiāng|sc=Hani}} {{trans-mid}} * Japanese: {{t-needed|ja}} {{trans-bottom}} ===Etymology 2=== ====Proper noun==== {{en-proper noun}} # {{misspelling of|en|Xinjiang}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1907 |last=Bruce |first=Clarence Dalrymple |chapter=V |title=In the Foot Steps of Marco Polo: Being the Account of a Journey Overland from Simla to Pekin |url=https://archive.org/details/cu31924023236742/ |location={{w|William Blackwood and Sons}} |oclc=1227363797 |page=93 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/cu31924023236742/page/n124/ |text=Chinese Turkestan is known to have been under the jurisdiction of that country as early as 150 B.C.
In the time of the great Han dynasty not only did their power extend to the present western boundary of the '''Hsing Chiang'''{{sic|Hsin Chiang}}, but even as far west as the Caspian their suzerainty was acknowledged. |brackets=on}} #* {{quote-journal |en |year=1980 |last=Ege |first=Konrad |title=U.S. Intervention in Afghanistan |journal={{w|CounterSpy (magazine)|CounterSpy}} |url=https://archive.org/details/sim_national-reporter_1980_4_1/ |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |volume=4 |issue=1 |issn=0739-4322 |oclc=702602544 |page=18 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/sim_national-reporter_1980_4_1/page/18/ |text=KYODO also states that, according to Indian intelligence sources, "the guerillas were sent from their training bases around Khasgar in '''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}} Province [in China] to the sensitive areas bordering Afghanistan".}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1985 |last=Han |first=Zhongmin |authorlink= |last2=Delahaye |first2=Hubert |title=A Journey Through Ancient China: From the Neolithic to the Ming |url=https://archive.org/details/journeythroughan00hanz/ |publisher={{w|Gallery Books}} |ISBN=0-8317-5225-4 |OCLC=956322650 |OL=8186720M |pages=21, 214 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/journeythroughan00hanz/page/214/ |text=In the northern part of China, from the north-east to '''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}}, the grassy plateaux were suitable for grazing by livestock and it is in this area that numerous microlithic finds — typical of a nomadic economy — have been made.{{...}}
The majority of Tang tombs discovered in other areas are similar to those found near Chang'an, but some do display distinctive features: at Astana, in the village of Karallja in the autonomous region of '''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}} Uygur, a large number of documents, silk paintings and other artefacts have been found.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1994 |last=Burrows |first=William E. |authorlink=William E. Burrows |last2=Windrem |first2=Robert |title=Critical Mass: The Dangerous Race for Superweapons in a Fragmenting World |url=https://archive.org/details/criticalmassdang00burr/ |publisher={{w|Simon & Schuster}} |ISBN=0-671-74895-5 |LCCN=93-36604 |OCLC=493517239 |OL=1425593M |page=347 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/criticalmassdang00burr/page/347/ |text='''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}} is part of the Urumqi Military Region, which includes all of '''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}} and western Tibet.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1998 |last=Strong |first=Terence |title=Deadwater Deep |url=https://archive.org/details/deadwaterdeep0000stro_x6v0/ |genre=Fiction |publisher={{w|Pocket Books}} |ISBN=978-1-84739-032-5 |OCLC=679877427 |OL=28267735M |page=168 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/deadwaterdeep0000stro_x6v0/page/168/ |text=We’ve seen it a hundred times in history. If a nation fears internal unrest - as Beijing does from the Muslims in '''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}} and growing millions of unemployed from ailing state industries - there is no better way to unify a country than by going to war with those you blame for your troubles.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=1999 |editor=Xiaoneng Yang |title=The Golden Age of Chinese Archaeology: Celebrated Discoveries from the People's Republic of China |url=https://archive.org/details/goldenageofchine00yang/ |publisher= |ISBN=0-300-08132-4 |LCCN=99-16620 |OCLC=1055607454 |OL=9341605M |page=43 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/goldenageofchine00yang/page/43/ |text=Archaeology in China, moreover, is not limited to underground excavations: archaeological techniques have been applied to the study of Buddhist caves and works of art in '''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}}, Central China, and Tibet, in order to establish their regional and temporal distributions.}} #* {{quote-book |en |year=2007 |last=Su |first=Shuyang |authorlink=Su Shuyang |translator=Chen Zijian |title=A Reader on China |url=https://archive.org/details/readeronchinaani0000sush/ |publisher=Better Link Press |ISBN=978-1-60220-103-3 |OCLC=1104395452 |OL=12554432M |page=28 |pageurl=https://archive.org/details/readeronchinaani0000sush/page/28/ |text=The Tarim River in '''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}} is the largest inland river in the country.}} #* {{quote-web |en |date=FEBRUARY 25, 2021 |title=Dutch parliament: China's treatment of Uighurs is genocide |work={{w|Reuters}} |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20210225190514if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-netherlands-china-uighurs-idUSKBN2AP2CI |archivedate=February 25, 2021 |text=In a statement on its website, the Chinese Embassy in The Hague said the Uighur population in Xinjiang has been growing in in recent years, enjoying a higher standard of living, and a longer life expectancy.
“How can you call this a genocide?” it said. “'''Xingjiang'''{{sic|Xinjiang}}-related issues are never about human rights, ethnicity or religion, but about combating violent terrorism and succession{{sic|secession}}.”}} #* {{quote-web |en |date=Nov 21, 2021 |author=Wu Su-wei |author2=Jonathan Chin |title=Uighurs could face more repression under new leaders |work={{w|Taipei Times}} |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20211120160621/https://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2021/11/21/2003768231 |archivedate=20 November 2021 |text=Beijing’s reshuffle of officials in '''Xingjiang''' might herald a hardening of repression against Uighurs, an academic at the Institute for National Defense and Security Research said.}} #* {{seemoreCites|en}} ===Further reading=== * {{R:OneLook}} * {{R:TheFreeDictionary}}
